page.title: 01Sea-Lochar Estuary & Solway
page.content: More than 50% of this square consists of the mouth of the Lochar, the merse (saltings) & the Solway Firth itself. The hinterland is farmed on reclaimed peat moss & the merse provides grazing for cattle. The shore line changes over the years sometimes the sea makes inroads on the land and them recedes. There is no fishing industry but the local people still 'tramp' flounders for their own use. Local History: There are interesting remains of salt pans along the shore. Salt-making was until the end of the last century a considerable industry here, the right having been conferred by Robert the Bruce. Recreation: This is wildfowling country - pink-feet geese and greylag coming in quantities; but the sport is well regulated by the local association.
